Graphical abstract This study enhances lithium-sulfur reaction efficiency by transforming MXene to a three-dimensional (3D) structure, increasing surface area and catalytic sites. Ti-V synergy boosts electron/ion transport, improving sulfur phase transitions and batteries lifespan. Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) chemistry reaction opens a new battery era with high energy density; meanwhile, multiple electrons migration leads to the complex phase transition of sulfur species. To manipulate the binding strength of multiple key intermediates more efficiently, the bimetallic TiVC MXene is utilized to realize multi-dimensional catalysis. Based on the macroscopic three-dimensional (3D) structure using two-dimensional (2D) MXene architecture, electron conductivity and sulfur utilization are improved. Microscopically, Ti-V catalytic systems regulate multiple reaction intermediates through intermetallic synergies customized surface properties and atomic scale coordination, thereby improving electronic and ionic conductivity. In-situ Raman spectroscopy and electrochemical analysis show that the conversion rate of polysulfides was accelerated during the charge-discharge process. The Ti-V interaction exhibits unique catalytic activity and regulates multiple continuous processes of sulfur species phase transformation, which are essential for the excellent energy performance of Li-S batteries. This study not only clarifies the catalytic mechanism of Ti-V at different dimensions but also proposes a promising strategy for the design of advanced catalytic systems in energy storage technology. Keywords Bimetallic MXene Three-dimensional structure Catalysis Lithium-sulfur batteries In-situ characterizations 1 Introduction Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries are considered highly promising for future energy storage technologies due to their high theoretical energy density (2600 Wh kg−1), low cost, and environmental benignity [1]. However, their practical application is hindered by the slow redox kinetics of sulfur species and the shuttle effect of lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) [2–6]. Catalysis has emerged as a promising approach, particularly through an adsorption-transformation-desorption mechanism that facilitates the conversion of liquid LiPSs into solid Li2S2/Li2S, thereby lowering LiPSs concentration in the electrolyte [7–13]. Among the various catalysts explored, MXenes have attracted widespread interest for their conductivity, rapid charge response, and specific surface area. During the solid-liquid-solid transformation of sulfur species, MXenes exhibit strong chemisorption and catalytic conversion capabilities, which enhance the conversion of LiPSs and improve redox activity [14–17]. Currently, MXene-based catalysts primarily focus on monometallic MXenes [18,19], such as Ti3C2 [20–22] and V2C [23–25]. However, monometallic MXenes contain only one type of metal element, resulting in a relatively simple energy level structure characterized by a straightforward bandwidth and energy level distribution [26]. This simplicity can lead to inferior energy level matching with specific reaction intermediates, thereby hindering charge transfer between the material surface and these intermediates. By diversifying the composition at the metal sites, bimetallic MXenes exhibit the potential to tailor specific properties. The introduction of a second element with dimensions like the main metal can modify the electronic structure of the metal sites within the lattice, enhancing the adsorption of reaction intermediates and addressing the limitations of monometallic MXenes. For instance, introducing the transition metal vanadium (V) into the transition metal layer of MXene results in the formation of the bimetallic solid solution TiVC. The interactions between elements in this solid solution are typically stronger, which enhances ion and electron transport within the material. Additionally, V possesses high oxidative activity, and its incorporation into MXene can improve catalytic efficiency toward LiPSs, reducing the formation of reaction intermediates. However, MXene tends to agglomerate and restack, which reduces the surface area, blocks active sites, and increases internal resistance, ultimately degrading catalytic performance [27,28]. Therefore, further research is needed to fully understand the catalytic interfaces, electronic properties, and overall performance [29–32]. Herein, inspired by the unique spatial structures and highly adjustable metal compositions of MXenes, three-dimensional (3D) bimetallic TiVC MXene catalysts were prepared based on an alkalization method (a-TiVC). The catalyst was employed as the catalytic cathode in Li-S batteries [33–35] and was focused on the catalytic capabilities of LiPSs. Structural characterization demonstrated that surface engineering preserves crystal structure, minimizes band gaps and internal resistance, and facilitates the full exposure of active sites. Additionally, in-situ characterization techniques revealed the catalytic mechanisms of this bimetallic catalyst for LiPSs. The a-TiVC exhibits tandem catalytic capabilities, improves the adsorption of LiPSs, reduces reaction barriers, and leverages synergistic interaction between Ti and V, enhancing interfacial chemical bonding [36–41]. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Preparation of TiVC nanosheets. Firstly, 2 g of lithium fluoride (LiF) powder was added into 20 mL of 12 M hydrochloric acid (HCl), and magnetic stirring was carried out at room temperature with a speed of 450 r min−1 and a stirring time of 20–30 min to make a homogeneous mixture. Then 1 g of TiVAlC ceramic powder was slowly added into the mixture, and the temperature was raised to 50 °C, and the mixture was stirred with continuous heating for 72 h. Subsequently, the mixture was centrifuged at 8000 r min−1 to collect the black precipitate and discard the supernatant, and the collected precipitate was centrifuged and washed with deionized water and ethanol several times until the pH reached about 5.5. Then the precipitate was mixed with ethanol and sonicated under nitrogen atmosphere for 2 h. The solution was filtered and freeze-dried to obtain TiVC nanosheets. Preparation of a-TiVC: 200 mg of dried and finished nanosheets were taken and 50 mL of deionized water was added and stirred to make a solution. At the same time, 50 mL of 4 M KOH solution was prepared and slowly added into the nanosheet solution under stirring. The solution was stirred continuously at room temperature for 24 h. Finally, the precipitate was collected by filtration and freeze-dried to obtain a-TiVC. 2.2 Batteries assembly and electrochemical testing Structure and morphology of TiVC nanosheets and a-TiVC. The prepared catalysts were characterized by an X-ray diffractometer operating (Karlsruhe, Germany) at 40 kV, 30 mA with Cu-K radiation (λ = 0.15405 nm), and the powder XRD patterns were collected in a range of diffraction angles (2θ) from 5° to 60°. The field emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM, FEI Nova Nano 450) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, FEI Tecnai G2 F20) equipped with high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) detectors were conducted to study the morphology and microstructures of the catalysts. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) characterizations were obtained by an ESCALAB 250 instrument (Waltham, USA) with Al K α X-rays (1489.6 eV, 150 W, 50.0 eV pass energy). Li-S batteries assembly. Firstly, the materials (TiVC, a-TiVC) and sublimation sulfur were mixed and milled uniformly according to the mass ratio of 3:7, kept warm at 155 °C for 12 h, and then heated to 180 °C and kept warm for 2 h. The positive electrode active material was prepared, and the active material, Cochin black, and polyvinylidene difluoride (PVDF) binder were mixed in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) according to the mass ratio of 7:2:1, milled to make a slurry to prepare the working electrode, and held in a vacuum at 55 °C for 12 h. After drying, it was cut into a circular piece with a diameter of 10 mm as the cathode. The sulfur loading of the cathode was about 1 mg cm−1. Subsequently, CR2032 coin batteries were assembled in an argon-filled glove box with humidity and oxygen concentration below 0.5 ppm, with pure lithium foil as the negative electrode and Celgard 2500 film as the diaphragm, and each battery was injected with 40 µL of electrolyte solution. The electrolyte solution consisted of 1.0 M lithium bis-triflfluoromethanesulphonylimide (LiTFSI) in 1:1 (v/v) 1,2-dimethoxyethane: 1,3-dioxolane (DME:DOL) and 1 wt% LiNO3. For Li-S batteries with high sulfur loading, electrolyte additions were made at an electrolyte/sulfur (E/S) ratio of 11:1. All batteries were set aside for 4–6 h before cycling to ensure that the electrolyte penetrated the electrodes sufficiently. Electrochemical performance was measured using a NEWARE-CT4008 instrument in a room temperature voltage window of 1.7–2.7 V vs. Li/Li+. The specific capacity was calculated based on the mass of sulfur. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves and electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) of the samples were determined using an electrochemical workstation. The voltages of CV test ranged from 1.7 to 2.8 V with a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1. EIS analyses were acquired in the range of 0.01 Hz to 100 kHz. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of a-TiVC The TiVAlC powder with MAX phase (Fig. S1) was etched with a LiF/HCl solution to selectively remove the Al atomic layer, resulting in multilayered TiVC [28,42,43]. SEM analysis (Fig. S2a) revealed the typical MXene multilayered structure and EDX spectroscopy (Fig. S2b) confirmed the elemental composition of Ti, V, and C. Fig. 1 (a) presents the XRD pattern analysis, where a distinct peak at 6.59° is characteristic of MXenes, indicating that the alkalization of the MXene does not change the structure. The multilayered MXene was then sonicated to expand interlayer spacing, transforming the accordion-like morphology to a two-dimensional (2D) monolayer structure (Fig. 1b). Transparent flakes observed by SEM further corroborated the formation of monolayer and few-layer TiVC (Fig. S3). High-resolution TEM (HRTEM) reveals a lattice spacing of 0.23 nm (Fig. S4). Following alkalization with KOH, TiVC nanosheets transform into nanoribbons due to ion exchange and directional crystal cleavage. The substitution of surface F groups by OH groups alters the chemical environment, while OH− ions selectively etch the weaker Ti–O and V–O bonds along specific crystal orientation, driving delamination and anisotropic restructuring into one-dimensional nanoribbons [38]. TEM (Fig. 1c) reveals an interwoven nanoribbon-nanosheet structure. As shown in Fig. 1(d), the crystal structure and plane spacing of a-TiVC nanosheets were analyzed using HRTEM images. These results confirmed that the nanosheets possess high crystallinity with a hexagonal close-packed (HCP) structure. A comparison with the pristine TiVC nanosheets reveals a leftward shift in the (002) peak and a slight increase in the full width at half maximum (FWHM), suggesting an enlargement of the interlayer spacing in the MXenes following the alkalization process, which aligns with the formation of nanoribbons. SEM and TEM images of a-TiVC illustrate the development of a 3D structure. HAADF-STEM and EDX elemental maps further show the distribution of C, O, Ti, and V elements within the a-TiVC catalyst (Fig. 1e and f). These results indicate that the nanobelts are uniformly derived from TiVC. XPS) was employed to identify the elemental composition and valence states in the a-TiVC MXene. The Ti 2p XPS peaks are observed at 457.1, 458.6, 462.6, and 464.3 eV, corresponding to Ti–C and Ti–O bonds, respectively (Fig. 1g). The V 2p XPS peaks are located at 513.7, 516.4, 521.0, and 532.8 eV, which are associated with V–C and V4+ species (Fig. 1h). The O 1s XPS spectra display three peaks denoted Ti–O, V–O and O–H (Fig. 1i). A comparison of the Ti 2p and V 2p XPS spectra of TiVC confirms that the structure of the a-TiVC MXene remains unchanged post-alkalization (FigS. S5 and S6) [44–48]. 3.2 Electrochemical characterization of a-TiVC The adsorption capacity of catalysts for LiPSs is crucial in Li-S batteries, as it not only mitigates the loss of active materials but also enhances the catalytic conversion of LiPSs on the catalyst surface. To evaluate the adsorption capacity of TiVC and a-TiVC, the static adsorption experiments were conducted using equal masses of each catalyst powder as adsorbents, with a fixed concentration and volume of Li2S6 solution [49,50]. The experimental results reveal that the solution containing a-TiVC catalysts was colorless after 2 h of immersion, whereas the solution with TiVC retained its color (Fig. 2 a). This observation is consistent with literature reports, indicating that a lighter color corresponds to a lower concentration of LiPSs. These results suggest that a-TiVC possesses a higher density of bimetallic sites, which form stronger interactions with LiPSs. To further elucidate the role of the a-TiVC catalyst in Li-S batteries, CV measurements were performed. The CV measurements were conducted at a rate of 0.1 mV s−1, with the voltage windows ranging from 1.7 to 2.8 V. The CV curves of the Li-S batteries exhibit two distinct reduction peaks and two oxidation peaks. Specifically, the oxidation peak at 2.5 V corresponds to the oxidation of Li2S2/Li2S to S8, which aligns with the charging plateau. Conversely, the reduction peak at 2.3 V is attributed to the reduction of long-chain LiPSs (Li2S n , 4 ≤ n ≤ 8), corresponding to the first discharge plateau. Notably, the reduction peaks (I, II) and oxidation peaks (I', II') for the a-TiVC catalyst are more compact compared to those for the TiVC catalyst, indicating a reduction in polarization (Fig. 2b and Table S1). To further evaluate the sulfur redox kinetics, the Tafel slope of the liquid-solid transition was computed, as displayed in Fig. 2(c). The Tafel slope for the a-TiVC battery in converting Li2S n to Li2S is 68.8 mV dec−1, which is lower than that of the TiVC battery being 102.9 mV dec−1. This reduction in Tafel slope for the a-TiVC battery indicates a more efficient catalytic conversion of long-chain LiPSs to short-chain LiPSs, attributed to the increased presence of Ti and V metals. The Tafel slope for the a-TiVC battery in converting Li2S to Li2S n is 65.4 mV dec−1. The lower Tafel slope observed for the oxidative process in a-TiVC signifies an enhanced kinetic rate for the conversion of LiPSs [51]. Additionally, the Li+ diffusion behavior was assessed through CV curves at varying scanning rates (0.1 to 0.5 mV s−1), and the Li+ diffusion coefficients for peaks I, II, and III were determined using the Randles-Sevcik equation [52]. The higher ionic diffusion coefficients are observed for the a-TiVC batteries, in comparison to the TiVC batteries, suggesting a more rapid diffusion of Li+ during the redox reactions (Fig. 2d, e and Fig. S7). These findings confirm that the increased exposure of bimetallic active sites in a-TiVC effectively lowers the energy barrier for Li+ diffusion, thereby accelerating the subsequent conversion of LiPSs. As illustrated in Fig. 2(f), to elucidate the catalytic abilities provided by a-TiVC in Li-S batteries, symmetric batteries with TiVC and a-TiVC electrodes were assembled. Both CV profiles display two pairs of redox peaks characteristic of LiPSs conversion. However, the a-TiVC symmetric batteries exhibit sharper and more pronounced peaks compared to the TiVC batteries, indicating improved kinetics of redox reaction during the liquid-liquid transformation. This indicates higher exposure of bimetallic catalytic sites and more effective promotion of LiPSs conversion, highlighting the superior catalytic performance of a-TiVC in Li-S batteries. To further elucidate the catalytic role in enhancing the conversion kinetics in Li-S batteries, the activation energy (E a) was assessed. Temperature-dependent CV experiments were conducted at various temperatures (40, 50, and 60 °C) to determine the E a associated with the liquid-solid phase transformation of LiPSs (Fig. 2g and Fig. S8) [53]. The peak current (j) in the CV curves is directly related to the reaction rate (k), allowing the application of the Arrhenius equation (j ∝ k = A × e−E a/ RT ). The fitting results presented in Fig. 2(h) reveal that a-TiVC exhibits a lower E a compared to TiVC. This lower activation energy indicates that a-TiVC significantly enhances the catalytic activity, facilitating a more efficient LiPSs conversion process in Li-S batteries. In Li-S batteries, the liquid-to-solid phase transition of sulfur species is a critical rate-limiting step due to its high energy barrier. To evaluate the catalytic performance of TiVC and a-TiVC in facilitating the transition processes, the Li2S deposition capability of both materials was investigated [54,55]. TiVC and a-TiVC were coated on carbon paper and assembled into asymmetric batteries with a Li2S8 solution as the electrolyte. The batteries were first discharged at a constant current until 2.06 V and then held at a constant voltage of 2.045 V. The results show that the Li2S deposition capacity of a-TiVC catalysts achieved 271.5 mAh g−1 (Fig. 3 a and b). SEM and EDX analysis (Fig. 3c and Fig. S9) confirmed the morphology and composition of the Li2S deposits. The results suggest that a-TiVC catalysts, with its greater exposure of bimetallic sites, lowered the nucleation energy barrier and promoted the rate of nucleation. In Li-S batteries, the reversible charging and discharging processes involve the dissolution of Li2S and conversion to S8, making efficient Li2S dissolution essential for cycling stability [56]. To investigate the problem, constant potential measurements were used. The a-TiVC cathode demonstrated the highest decomposition capacity of 671.5 mAh g−1, surpassing that of the TiVC cathode (Fig. 3d and e). SEM and EDX analysis revealed that the a-TiVC electrode surface became smoother with significantly reduced sulfur content (Fig. 3f and Fig. S10). This indicates that bimetallic sites of a-TiVC enhance the dissolution of Li2S during charging by facilitating electron and ion transfer at the electrode interface, thereby improving battery performance. 3.3 Electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries with the a-TiVC catalyst To investigate the impact of a-TiVC catalysts, Li-S batteries were assembled using TiVC and a-TiVC, with lithium metal as the cathode. Fig. 4 (a) shows the capacities of the a-TiVC cathode at varying current densities (0.1 to 2 C), which were 1157.6, 928.4, 807.1, 719.3, 692.3, and 656.2 mAh g−1, respectively. When the current density was reduced back to 0.1 C, the capacity increased to 884.3 mAh g−1, which is higher than that of the TiVC electrode. The a-TiVC battery shows a much lower overpotential (159.0 mV) than the TiVC battery (194.6 mV), indicating the faster electrochemical conversion kinetics of LiPSs (Fig. 4b and Fig. S11a). To further evaluate the effect of TiVC and a-TiVC, EIS was performed. As shown in Fig. 4(c), the results indicate that the a-TiVC electrode exhibits lower R e and R ct values compared to TiVC, suggesting improved charge transfer efficiency (Table S2), demonstrating that the 3D conductive network of a-TiVC facilitates faster electron and ion transport, enhancing overall electrode performance. The cycling stability of the two cathodes was assessed at a rate of 0.2 C, as illustrated in Fig. 4(d). The initial specific capacity of the a-TiVC cathode is 927.2 mAh g−1. After 400 cycles at 0.2 C, a-TiVC retains a specific capacity of 467.13 mAh g−1, demonstrating excellent stability, while TiVC shows a reduced discharge capacity of 350.26 mAh g−1 under the same conditions. Furthermore, with a sulfur mass loading of 5.20 mg cm−2 and an electrolyte-to-sulfur ratio of 11:1, the a-TiVC batteries maintain high capacity after 100 cycles at a lower current rate of 0.05 C (Fig. 4e, Figs. S11b and S12). 3.4 Reaction kinetics of LiPSs catalyzed by a-TiVC To examine the transformation of LiPSs in Li-S batteries during charging and discharging cycles, we utilized the experimental setup shown in Fig. S13 and evaluated how effectively the electrode materials mitigate the shuttling effect. This setup allowed the laser incident beam to pass through a quartz observation window for real-time qualitative detection of LiPSs on the cathode side, with in-situ Raman spectra recorded under constant-current discharge conditions [57–60]. Fig. 5 presents Raman images of TiVC and a-TiVC electrodes at various voltage states throughout the charging and discharging processes. During discharge, S8 is progressively converted into LiPSs, while charging reversibly oxidizes the short-chain Li2S2/Li2S back to S8. For TiVC electrodes (Fig. 5a and b), the characteristic peaks corresponding to S4 2− and S3 2− were consistently observed throughout both charging and discharging, indicating the presence of the shuttle effect and slower LiPSs conversion kinetics. In contrast, the Raman signals of LiPSs in the alkali-treated a-TiVC electrode were largely undetectable during both discharge and charge cycles (Fig. 5c and d). This observation suggests that the a-TiVC electrode effectively adsorbs and facilitates the rapid conversion of LiPSs on the cathode side, thereby significantly reducing the LiPSs shuttling phenomenon and enhancing the conversion kinetics. To further investigate the catalytic transformation of LiPSs on a-TiVC, XPS was conducted at various states during the charging and discharging cycles (Fig. 5e and Fig. S14). The XPS results show that the characteristic peak of Li–S appeared at 2.1 and 1.7 V, which correspond to LiPSs and Li2S/Li2S2, diminishing in intensity during the charge process. With the electron capture and loss process of sulfur species, the S–S binding energy shifts distinctly. The formation of Ti–S and V–S peaks suggests that Ti and V chemically bond with sulfur atoms in the LiPSs. This interaction between the Ti, V transition metals and LiPSs concurrently facilitates the transformation of LiPSs, highlighting the catalytic efficacy of a-TiVC in improving sulfur redox processes. In conjunction with the TEM characterization results (Fig. 5f), it was observed that a-TiVC exhibited a significant formation of Li2S particles on its surface by the end of the discharge process. This finding corroborates the Raman spectroscopy data, and further demonstrates the enhanced catalytic conversion of LiPSs by a-TiVC. Upon completion of the charging cycle, a-TiVC retained its 3D interwoven structure, demonstrating notable structural stability, which is advantageous for improving cycling performance. During the discharge process of Li-S batteries, the liquid-solid phase transformation contributes significantly, accounting for three-quarters of the total capacity. However, the accumulation of intermediate products increases the internal impedance, which restricts the redox kinetics. Therefore, analyzing the EIS data can provide valuable insights into the complex sulfur redox reactions and the changes occurring at the cathode of the Li-S battery [61–65]. We conducted in-situ impedance measurements on the battery at different charge and discharge states (Fig. 6 a and b). As illustrated in Fig. 6(c and d), at the beginning of the discharge process, the conversion of solid S8 into long-chain LiPSs primarily affects the high-frequency region, which is related to the evolution of electrolyte resistance. As the LiPSs concentration increases, high-frequency impedance rises slightly, while low-frequency impedance decreases. The formation of intermediates results in the solid electrode interface, causing the obstacles of charge transfer at the electrode/electrolyte interface. This manifests as two semicircles in the high-to-mid frequency range. The formation of soluble long-chain LiPSs inevitably increases the viscosity of the electrolyte. However, during the discharge process, long-chain LiPSs are converted into short-chain LiPSs, which participate more in surface construction. High-frequency impedance gradually decreases as solid Li2S begins to form, and the consumption of soluble materials reduces electrolyte viscosity, thereby lowering electrolyte resistance. During the charging, reversible reactions occur, accompanied by the dissolution of solid Li2S, which in turn leads to an increase in electrolyte viscosity. In comparison with TiVC, a-TiVC has more active sites and shows minimal change in impedance throughout the charging process compared to the initial discharge. Conversely, the electrolyte resistance of TiVC does not return to its initial value and remains slightly elevated. This difference in behavior may contribute to the fact that even at the end of the first discharge and charge cycles, some LiPSs remain in the electrolyte, indicating incomplete reversibility, as supported by the in-situ Raman results. The results demonstrate that a-TiVC enhances the redox kinetics of LiPSs during the charge and discharge processes. 4 Conclusions The unique characteristics of intermediate species in the Li-S chemistry suggest that constructing a TiVC MXene bimetallic catalyst with intermetallic synergy is an effective strategy to optimize the reaction pathway and enhance overall catalytic activity. By employing an alkalization method, the surface functional group hydrolysis of the MXene induces the dissolution and reconstruction of transition metals into a 3D structure. This process significantly increases the specific surface area and generates abundant catalytic sites, which are crucial for enhancing the Ti-V catalytic activity. The Ti-V intermetallic synergy significantly enhances the electron and ion transport between the catalytic interface and LiPSs, facilitating more efficient reactions. This multi-faceted catalytic approach leverages the synergistic effects of 3D structural and intermetallic interactions, where the a-TiVC MXene catalyst not only enhances mass transfer during the Li-S reaction but also optimizes the electronic and ionic interactions at the catalyst interface, thereby facilitating seamless phase transitions. Electrochemical analysis demonstrates that the catalyst exhibits high capacity and excellent cycling stability, sustaining 467.13 mAh g−1 after 400 cycles. This study emphasizes the importance of bimetallic catalysts and multi-dimensional catalysis in optimizing catalytic performance, offering a new approach to improving energy storage systems. coredata.dc:description: Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) chemistry reaction opens a new battery era with high energy density; meanwhile, multiple electrons migration leads to the complex phase transition of sulfur species. To manipulate the binding strength of multiple key intermediates more efficiently, the bimetallic TiVC MXene is utilized to realize multi-dimensional catalysis. Based on the macroscopic three-dimensional (3D) structure using two-dimensional (2D) MXene architecture, electron conductivity and sulfur utilization are improved. Microscopically, Ti-V catalytic systems regulate multiple reaction intermediates through intermetallic synergies customized surface properties and atomic scale coordination, thereby improving electronic and ionic conductivity. In-situ Raman spectroscopy and electrochemical analysis show that the conversion rate of polysulfides was accelerated during the charge-discharge process. The Ti-V interaction exhibits unique catalytic activity and regulates multiple continuous processes of sulfur species phase transformation, which are essential for the excellent energy performance of Li-S batteries. This study not only clarifies the catalytic mechanism of Ti-V at different dimensions but also proposes a promising strategy for the design of advanced catalytic systems in energy storage technology.
